newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's Kinkel warns Milosevic of new sanctions.
newsitem.headline: Germany's Kinkel warns Milosevic of new sanctions.

text.p: Germany's Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel warned Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic on Saturday Yugoslavia could face renewed economic sanctions unless it recognised all opposition victories in November elections.

Kinkel's remarks were released by German newspaper Bild am Sonntag, shortly before a senior political source in Belgrade said Milosevic was expected to acknowledge opposition election victories with a call to form a coalition government.

In a commentary released ahead of publication on Sunday, Kinkel said it was not enough for Milosevic to recognise only some of the poll wins by the opposition Zajedno (Together) coalition. Authorities annulled the results, citing electoral irregularities.
"Milosevic must recognise opposition victories in all constituencies where they were annulled, without delay," Kinkel said.
Kinkel said the European Union had already halted economic aid to Yugoslavia but could step up pressure by isolating the country further with economic sanctions.

"We are not talking about economic sanctions yet, but the long-suffering population would bear the brunt of these the most," he said. "Those who deceive voters in their own country are preventing the Serbs from finding their place in Europe."
